facts.text: Supreme Court holds plaint not a nullity, amendment correctly allowed as misdescription.

facts.text: Dunderdale signed and verified the plaint on Power of Attorney.

issues.text: Whether the plaint as filed was a nullity making the suit incompetent and whether bringing the partners on record amounts to addition of new parties after the period of limitation

anchor.surface_text: It was urged on behalf of the appellants that  1  the plaint as filed was a nullity. The suit, therefore, was incompetent. To bring on the record the partners of the firm amounted to addition of new parties and if on the date these partners are added as parties and the period of limitation had elapsed then the entire suit would be time barred

issues.text: Whether the provisions of O. 1, r. 10 or O. VI, r. 17 have any application to the case

anchor.surface_text: even if it be held that the plaint is not a nullity, neither the provisions of 0. 1, r. 10 nor those of O. VI, r. 17 have any application to the case

issues.text: Whether having regard to s. 45 of the Indian Contract Act a suit by only one partner is bad and any amendment would convert it into a new suit barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: having regard to the provisions of s. 45 of the Indian Contract Act a suit by only one partner or one promisee is bad to start with. There being no suit by all the partners, any amendment, if allowed, would convert the old suit into a new suit and the new suit would be barred by limitation

issues.text: Whether allowing the amendment would be adding or substituting new plaintiffs deemed instituted on the date they are made parties under s. 22(1) Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: if the amendment was allowed it would be a case of adding or substituting new plaintiffs and as regards them it would be deemed to have been instituted when they were made parties. Reference to s. 22 (1), Indian Limitation Act, was made in this connection.

issues.text: Whether there was no suit in the eyes of the law as the plaint was not verified or signed as required by law

arguments.claim: Firm not legal entity but existing concern; suit in firm name is by partners.

holdings.text: The Division Bench of the High Court took a correct view in holding that the plaint was not a nullity. It was a case of a suit instituted by all the partners of a firm who were misdescribed as Manilal Sons, a firm carrying on business at No. 11A Malacca Street, Singapore.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the Division Bench of the High Court took a correct view in holding that the plaint was not a nullity. It was a case of a suit instituted by all the partners of a firm who were misdescribed as Manilal Sons, a firm carrying on business at No. 11A Malacca Street,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Firm name describes partners collectively; suit by foreign firm is by partners with defective description, not nullity.

holdings.text: The word firm or the firm name is merely a compendious description of all the partners collectively.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, hereinafter referred to as the Act, states that Partnership is the relation between persons who have agreed to share the profits of a business carried on by all or any of them acting for all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of Section 4 Partnership Act defining firm name as collective description of partners.

holdings.text: Where a suit is filed in the name of a firm it is still a suit by all the partners of the firm unless it is proved that all the partners had not authorized the suit.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical consequence from s.4; rebuttable presumption all partners authorize unless proved otherwise.

holdings.text: A firm may not be a legal entity in the sense of a corporation or a company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act but it is still an existing concern where business is done by a number of persons in partnership. When a suit is filed in the name of a firm it is in reality a suit by all the partners of the firm.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Firm lacks juridical personality but suit in firm name is effectively by partners.

holdings.text: Even if the provisions of O. 1, r. 10 and O. VI, r. 17 did not strictly apply the amendment could be permitted under s. 153 of the Civil Procedure Code because it was not a case of either adding parties or substituting parties.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Misdescription correctable under s.153 CPC as no addition/substitution of parties.

holdings.text: The existence of the provisions of O. XXX in the Code does not mean that a plaint filed in the name of a firm doing business outside India is not a suit in fact by the partners of that firm individually.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Order XXX enabling for Indian firms only; foreign partners may sue individually, firm name is misdescription.

holdings.text: A plaint filed in a court in India in the name of a firm doing business outside India is not by itself a nullity. It is a plaint by all the partners of the firm with a defective description of themselves for the purposes of the Code of Civil Procedure.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesis of Partnership Act and CPC; defective but valid plaint by partners.

holdings.text: We have no doubt, on a perusal of the Power of Attorney, that it authorized Dunderdale to file the plaint on behalf of the firm Manilal Sons and also to verify it.

anchor.surface_text: Dunderdale had signed and verified the plaint in the present case. We have no doubt, on a perusal of the Power of Attorney, that it authorized Dunderdale to file the plaint on behalf of the firm Manilal Sons and also to verify it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct examination of POA document confirms authorization.

holdings.text: It was not necessary that the Power should have been signed by all the partners of the firm because Manubhai Maganbhai Amin was the manager of the firm. Under s. 18 of the Act a partner is an agent of the firm for the purposes of the business of the firm.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Manager partner acts as agent under s.18 Partnership Act.

holdings.text: Under s. 19(2) of the Act instances are stated where... the implied authority of a partner does not empower him to do matters mentioned in cls. (a) to (h). It is significant that in these clauses there is no prohibition to a partner executing a Power of Attorney...
holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory limit on manager's authority to execute POA for suit.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the Division Bench of the High Court took a correct view in holding that the plaint was number a nullity. It was a case of a suit instituted by all the partners of a firm who were misdescribed as Manilal Sons, a firm carrying on business at No. 11A Malacca Street, Singapore and., accordingly the learned Judges rightly allowed the plaint to be amended on terms and conditions stated in their order. It follows therefore that the High Court was also right in setting aside the decree of P. B. Mukherjea, J., dismissing the suit.

outcome.relief_summary: Division Bench order upheld; plaint amendment allowed by substituting names of partners for firm name; trial court decree dismissing suit set aside
